dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Host_B, have you been following these US-China trade talks? I gotta say, the article here makes it sound like they're actually, um, moving towards a surprisingly swift and successful conclusion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I know! It's kinda wild, right? Like, after all the back and forth, they're saying it's a "harmonious blend" of negotiating styles that's really pushing it forward.

dialogue_turns.text: Right? But here's the kicker, this professor from Columbia Business School, he actually discourages talking about these cultural differences in negotiation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? But here's the kicker, this professor from Columbia Business School, he actually discourages talking about these cultural differences in negotiation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In my class, I suggest to the students that before their two teams sit down to negotiate, they should first discuss and try to agree on the norms that will govern the talks and not simply assume that their own norm is universally shared.

dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, really? That seems, uh, totally counterintuitive. Like, wouldn't you want to discuss them to avoid issues?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, his point is that discussing them *creates* division. Instead, he says embracing differences is key. And he uses this example of, like, US versus Chinese negotiation styles.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, his point is that discussing them creates division. Instead, he says embracing differences is key. And he uses this example of, like, U S versus Chinese negotiation styles.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Discussing how to negotiate before the talks start would reduce the chances of such a clash, and therefore save a great deal of disappointment and frustration further down the road.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, tell me more. What's the difference?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, tell me more. What's the difference?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Americans, they often take a holistic approach, right? Like, they want a general agreement on overall goals first, even if there are nine topics. The Chinese, though, they're more checklist-oriented. They agree item by item.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Americans, they often take a holistic approach, right? Like, they want a general agreement on overall goals first, even if there are nine topics. The Chinese, though, they're more checklist-oriented. They agree item by item.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Most American negotiators adopt a checklist approach: if they wish to cover nine topics, they would like to reach agreement on each one in turn. The Chinese, by contrast, are accustomed to taking a more holistic approach, and follow a norm of nothing is agreed until everything is agreed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Ah, so, if they agree on the first six topics, the Chinese side might just have vague expectations for the last three? And if those last three go as expected, they just... don't revisit the first six?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ah, so, if they agree on the first six topics, the Chinese side might just have vague expectations for the last three? And if those last three go as expected, they just... don't revisit the first six?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When the discussion about these three topics turned out to be quite different from what they had expected, they asked to revisit the first six, because the various tradeoffs among the nine topics had changed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And the American side might think, "Oh, they're so trustworthy, everything's smooth!" But really, it's just how the Chinese operate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And the American side might think, Oh, they're so trustworthy, everything's smooth! But really, it's just how the Chinese operate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At this point, the American team may very well feel that the Chinese side is untrustworthy or insincere, and the whole negotiation may break down as a result.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So it's not the *difference* in style that makes talks collapse, but a lack of effort to understand and accommodate it? Like, a mismatch in expectations?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's not the difference in style that makes talks collapse, but a lack of effort to understand and accommodate it? Like, a mismatch in expectations?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But a clash of expectations can result if the two sides are not aware of these different styles.
